newsitem.title: USA: Rich working with FAA to resume flights.
newsitem.headline: Rich working with FAA to resume flights.

text.p: Rich International Airways, grounded by the Federal Aviation Administration last week, has developed a plan to address the FAA's safety concerns and get back into the air, a company spokesman said.

"The FAA has named a team of inspectors to work with us," said spokesman Mike Clark, and "we are busily working away to take care of their concerns." He declined to estimate when Rich might be flying again.

The Miami-based all-charter airline was grounded by the air safety agency on September 2 due to safety concerns. The privately held airline carries little cargo, but its 21 planes stranded about 15,000 people in mid-vacation.
Rich worked with tour operators and other airlines to get all the passengers home, Clark said.

Rich has had safety problems before. It was grounded in 1984 and in April the FAA proposed a $2.6 million fine on Rich, which the airline is contesting. Clark said in 27 years of operation, the airline has never had a death or injury.
